Note: Finished main progression now, about halfway through the story. Will update review on story if opinion changes.  Wow. What a journey. When Tiyuri first started saying that he left the Terraria team to work on his own game I was hyped. I was excited when the website went up. I read the dev posts and when footage of the game got released it looked like exactly what I was hoping for in a Terraria successor. The weapons I find are unique and amazing, the story ( playing as a human with apex and glitch friends ) is enticing and a little sad. You feel something different depending on your race. Humans will feel incredibly lonely. Apex will feel free when examining their race's 1984 type cities. Glitch will, well, chivalry n ♥♥♥♥.  First off, the main progression. From copper to solarium. The costs of gear are now relatively low, allowing for rapid progession and more time to do the main story and explore. But attaining the resources in the first place? Who'd have thought you could make it so varied? When I first figured out where to get free fuel, the surprises lying in wait made me go ' maybe i'll just buy it and start mining it when I have better gear '. I won't spoil anything, but something changes each tier. Maybe armour will begin to branch off, maybe a new enemy will attempt to stop you. For anyone who's played Terraria, you'll understand the basic gist of it. But Starbound's procedurally generated planets and enviroments make looking for ore that much fun. Even looking for cosmetics or furniture is a blast. Are you looking for some Apex furniture? They set up their cities on frozen planets, so look around there. But doesn't this look different from the last frozen planet you were on?  Yes, it does. Starbounds planet generation has improved massively since the beta. Planets now have their own mini-biomes depending on the location of the sun. The planet might be described as a volcanic planet, but this planet will have jungles, rivers and deserts. Some planets will be predictable. You probably guessed that ocean planets are mainly large bodies of water. But even then, the floor of these oceans will have their own secrets to explore. I never got bored of exploring planets, even if they were supposed to be similar.  The story starts off strong and incorporates itself into the main game really well. It revolves around items you have to discover by going to pre-made dungeons and fighting bosses. In order to find these dungeons you must find clues in settlements of a specific race. You're given clues as to where to find these settlements and finding one with the info you need becomes hugely satisfying. I'm not done with it yet but it so far seems pretty good.  Co-op has been made much easier, with Steam allowing drop-in drop-out co-op for up to 4 players. More than 4, however, will require dedicated servers to be made by one of your friends. The steam servers seem relatively strong, with little latency between me and my friends save for some spotty bits during long-distance games.   Overall, this is definitely an essential for fans of sci-fi exploration. Also a must-buy for fans of Terraria. Everything ties in really well and it's exactly what I expected. While multiplayer with more than 4 friends can be a hassle and the game still lacks a few features, ( I get the idea of finding a cute stowaway, but I'm not a cat person. I just want a dog, dammit. Now I'm stuck with this feline that doesn't eat anything I feed it. ) the game is a solid 9/10. They plan to support the game with updates after release, so this could change to a 10/10 if they add features the community are asking for. So what are you waiting for? Go Starbound already!

Going to come back for a full review later, but here's my quick review:  Gameplay: Really good, especially if you like platformers or sandbox games, or anything like Terraria. A lot of mechanics are similar to Terraria but definitely different enough to be it's own game. It's much tougher, HP doesn't regen, the energy system means you have to be smart with your weapon and tech usage, fall damage can kill you very easily, for instance. Exploration is very fun and rewarding, although it can get a bit repetitive after a while. There are TONS of different planets occupied by lots of different mobs and several races that have their own unique settlements, as well as dungeons, biomes, loot, quests etc etc there isn't a shortage of things to do. Movement feels fluid and fun and combat is really surprisingly involved and strategic.   Sound and music: Awesome. I love the soundtrack in this game, and all the sound effects for mining, combat etc sound great and perfectly fit into the sci-fi sandbox world.  Story: Definitely needs some work, but it appears the devs are fully aware of this and are working hard to expand it, which is great because what is there definitely works. The main quest is fun and the bosses are tough but fulfilling once beaten, and the different races and characters are all very charming and lovable. The game has tons of personality, so I'm very excited to see the direction the devs take with it.   Graphics: Pretty much what you'd expect, maybe a little better than Terraria. Pretty pixel art with a lot of love put into it. The characters are well designed, the races are very imaginative and look great. The world(s) itself is really neat, I don't know to what extent the worlds are procedurally generated but they are very well put together look beautiful. It all feels very alive.   A couple miscellaneous points:      I would like to see more biome diversity. As it is the different biomes look really pretty but they mostly play the same, and the underground layers don't seem to have too much variety.     One thing that I prefer about Terraria is the equipment system (including weapons, armor, accessories etc). In Terraria each piece of equipment seems unique, and it's a great feeling to take two awesome items and combine them into an even more awesome item, or to farm a boss or mob just to get that one special item. Starbound's weapons are mostly randomly generated and all feel somewhat similar, and armor is mostly just what you craft (and there aren't too many options at the moment). This is okay but I feel deserves more depth.     The Matter Manipulator is one of my favorite mechanics in this game. Instead of a typical pickaxe, shovel, axe, etc. you have a dedicated tool for all of your matter manipulating needs, including digging, mining, building, placing and removing objects and walls, gathering liquids, etc. This also includes an upgrade system with upgrades like faster manipulation speed and increasing the size of the area you can manipulate.      Expansion of the tech system is a must. Techs add functionality to your character mostly in the form of movement upgrades, like double jump, dash, or what is basically a morph ball. There used to be lots of cool tech upgrades but now it's just the three I listed with three (sort of) upgrades for each of them.   All in all, I love the game. I anticipate putting many more hours into it and I'm very excited for whatever the devs come up with next.

After several years, they've finally gone and finished it. Props to you, Chucklefish. This game holds a special place in my heart.  Starbound is one of those games that's good with a few mods and/or friends/servers to ♥♥♥♥ around with. Worth the price tag.    ...Of course, I suppose you want a far less concise review, so here you go.   Starbound is a 2D sidescrolling sandbox; you can think of it in a way as a spacefaring Terraria.  Many elements of the game are randomly generated. Most monsters are pre-made, but there are several variants with random body parts. Weapons are one of the most prominent random features; each possesses a different appearance and a special ability.  By far the most unique feature is the spacefaring. Starbound has you travelling around in your starship, discovering new and alien worlds on your quest to defeat the being which destroyed Earth.  Each planet and biome has exclusive loot, and occasionally you can find a settlement! The villagers can give you randomly generated quests, which you can complete for small rewards. Some may even wish to join you on your adventures! These new crewmembers become shipmates which can follow you around and give several passive buffs; some include the Soldier, Medic, Engineer, Tailor, and totally-not-useless Janitor.  Many unique premade weapons and other items can also be found on these planets, in addition to the random weapons; some are humorous, others creepy or downright strange.  Steam multiplayer and servers are also available for people who want to adventure together, or simply get together.  Modding is one of the game's finer aspects. Modding Starbound is nearly as easy as it gets; it simply requires a bit of knowledge of .json and .Lua code. There's even a mod folder directly in the game files! You can find many, many,  many  of these mods on the Workshop. Experiment a little and find what  you  like in your game!

I picked up this game when it was in beta way back in... well, before they went dark. Terrarria on steroids it looked like, and development was going nicely. After it went dark, reputation for the company fell and understandably, people got angry, myself included. By now though, Chucklefish has returned and I must say, I am pleased with the results of their supercharged comeback. A proper story, pets, procedurally generated universe that never ends, an infinite amount of side quests to keep you going, a tenant system that can be customized as a theme-per-room to attract specific races to live in your apartment complexes, a crew, workshop integration, combat tweaks with combos and special abilities, upgrades to the matter manipulator and your self, the changes to the crafting system - there's just so many things I could list and so many more I haven't even found but I am looking forward to. The most important thing is the shift from TCP/IP connections to being able to work with your steam friends list for easy multiplayer setup with your friends. The choice between casual (little penalty on death, no hunger, etc) survival (hunger, etc) and hardcore (one life, survival features, etc.) is also pretty nice.  It's definitely worth the $15, and if you love things like Terrarria, I could not suggest this game any more. It's a must-have.   There are things I am not happy with, of course; the new item bar system is confusing at best sometimes, and I don't really like how the classic backgrounds given for each race have been discarded for a universal story. I enjoyed taking my Glitch from her Outcast background and envisioning her adventures from that kind of perspective. At this moment in time I cannot think of anything else I dislike about the game, though if it comes to it, I will return at a later time to refine and update issues.  For now, I love this game, and have spent a *lot* of hours in it, and recommend it highly.

I was part of the initial Kickstarter to get this game going and have dedicated dozens of hours during the course of its development to a 1.0 release.  Starbound walks the line between a game with objectives put upon the player to encourage exploration and giving room for those who make objectives of their own. For those that look for nothing more in a game but to fritter away hours building up something for the sake of having done it, this game is for you. For those that don't care to follow instructions but want to be guided by a forceful hand to reach the end... you will probably be disappointed.  Story progression occurs through a series of missions and are accessible realatively early on. Being equipped well enough to complete them is another matter and people wanting a very linear experience will have to come to grips with some griding and exploring to see some of the sauce that makes this game just a little bit special.  Starboud is easy to recommend if you want something casual, light-hearted, and slow-paced.

tl;dr: if you enjoy building with a mix of exploring and combat, this game is for you. And if you get bored with vanilla game, its mod support is fantastic - so there are already tens of great and surprisingly complex mods to spice it up.  Long version:  I was a little wary of trying Starbound at first, but afterwards I've sunk a few hundred hours into it. Now I can safely say that if you are looking for a game that is a mix of building, exploring and combat, this is definitely a game for you. It does not excel in either combat or exploring, but both of them are fun to do - and later on you can take all the newly-found shiny loot and add it to your growing house and colony. The main story, although not great in itself, is also a nice diversion between regular exploration and colony building - the quests themselves are quite simplistic and same-y, but the instances that you do between them are varied and fun (and each has a chance to drop a unique weapon too).  The game is of course not ideal. The main story, as I've said, is quite simplistic and could be better. Equipment and gear progression is sometimes 'too balanced' - although some gear is quite unique visually, it is often underpowered compared to the 'boring' vanilla randomly-generated weapons, so you often end up using those. And mechanics such as tenants can sometimes leave you wanting them to be just a little deeper.  The above however, despite how it may sound, is not such a big issue in my opinion. The game is simply fun to play and although some parts of it are a bit shallow, there are enough of them to provide hours of fun for an aspiring builder/explorer. And as mentioned before, the game is VERY moddable and the modding scene is very active. There are already mods that add a ton of new things, expand the game progression dramatically and smooth out its rough edges. They are also seamlessly integrated via Steam Workshop and very easy to install - so don't be afraid to try them out.  In summary: the game is not perfect, but provides a lot of fun for people who like building, exploring and some platformer combat.  PROS:  - very nice graphics, with smooth animation and a large variation of potential building blocks that you can use  - enjoyable instances, challenge rooms and microdungeons  - good variety of activities that you can take part in  - FANTASTIC mod support, with a ton of mods dramatically expanding the game  CONS:  - main story is a bit lacking  - game is too balanced at times, which makes some weapons and techs a bit boring   - some mechanics, although functional, could be more developed

Starbound is not like Terraria and that's a mistake. Starbound is a sandbox game with narrow paths and empty purpose. The game has no soul. It doesn't know what it wants to be and I think the developers definitely gave too much attention to their 'white knight' fans. You have to be interested only in the artistry of this game, I think, to enjoy it. I've owned it since the kickstarter and the first betas years ago. Here's a summary of what I have to say.  The progression is super short and mostly boring.  The combat is novel but always boils down to best damage rather than style, tactic or build/class.  Boss fights are lame and not a challenge. Monsters in general are rarely challenging (I personally never felt challenged).  The questing is absolutely terrible. It truly feels as though no thought or care was given to whether or not ANY of the quests would be fun. I personally only enjoyed the Glitch castle defense in the main quest.  You can complete all progression in the game from the starting screen galaxy viewer on your ship. Even though there is a gargantuan universe available for exploration.  There is close to nothing going on below the surface of any planet and most materials mined have no need or even a use.  The interesting aspects of Starbound were not included in the progression of the game. Such as colonies and most crafting. In fact I beat the last boss with gear I bought from merchants on the highest tier planets. I never crafted a single weapon or piece of armor. Only the EPP units I needed to survive. Of which I had the best version of in a little over an hour of play. I'm not a speed player either. I'm a completionist. I like to take my time and casually set goals rather than bulldoze the content but Starbound rarely rewarded my exploration.  One technically plays a protector of the universe and it never mattered. I never had to build a colony or save a world from alien invasion. Never had to hunt down space pirates or evacuate a system from a dying star. All I had to do was planet hop. Scaling the surface for a few minutes each time to find chests. Then mine a little. Upgrade. Rinse and repeat.  But, you can make a pretty hotel, prison or cabin next to a lava river.  I would say: Don't buy it.

Not sure why I'm writing this since it'll probs just get lost but anyhow, here's my review of this game.   I originally purchased this game around it's initial 'Early Release' release over two years ago. The game back then seemed too vanilla. The concept was very intreguing. Being a huge fan of Terraria, the idea of that game on a much bigger scale really held my interest. To my disappointment, the game didn't have much to offer. Once you 'beat' the game, which only took a day or two of playing, there was just nothing to do. And by 'beat' i just mean aquire the best armor and weapons really. There wasn't really any story at the time.  Fast forward to now. 1.0 is released and the game has changed drastically. One day, a few weeks back, I decided to try this game out once more. It was all over the home page of Steam and it really made me want to give it one more chance, at least to the point where I felt like it was worth the buy. Well, I can honestly say that, after playing for another 20 hours or so and beating the main story, it isn't a bad game. The story progression is decent, the game mechanics are smooth, and it is overall an enjoyable experience. Before I explain any more in detail, I will list a few of my personal pros and cons.  Pro: -Fun with friend (Multiplayer) -Good sense of completion/accomplishment after completing main story quests -Plays well (Good weapon/tool mechanics) -Has a lot more potential  Cons: -Quite boring alone (In my own opinion) -Story is a bit too short -Story missions are a bit too repetitive -Final boss is the main one that doesn't feel very rewarding (also too easy and quick) -Has a lot more potential  The reason I put 'Has a lot more potential' on both is because it really is both good and bad. It's good that the developers have room to make the game better, but it's also not too good because at points, the game still doesn't feel fully complete. There also needs to be more variation in the main story. Every mission is just (spoiler warning possibly) scan (race) objects -> teleport to (race) location -> defeat boss. It just feels too wash-rinse-repeat. Anyhow, on a better note, the game is actually enjoyable with friends. Mining and building with others is fun, and upgrading your ship and EPP provides a fun feeling of progression. Exploring the various environments and fighting the different enemies is both exciting and annoying, but hey, I think those feelings combined make these type of games good. If it's never a little annoying, it's probably not challenging, and cake-walk games aren't generally as fun. The weapon/armor progressions/tiers were a bit confusing. It was a bit tricky to figure out when you really had the best things in the game, and the wiki wasnt much help. It seems to still be in the progress of being updated. Anyhow, let's wrap all this mess up into a conclusion.  Starbound is a fun game if you have another person to play with. If you are looking for a game that has a lot of replayability, I do not believe this is a game for you. It's fun to play through the main story once, maybe twice, but much more it just feels to overdone and boring. If you are okay with that, this game is a good buy. I was pleased with the newest update. If they add more to the story, I will consider playing again, but for now, once was enough. Like I said, there is definetly more that this game could be, the question is, will any more come of it?

Simultaneously endearing and addicting, Starbound is one game capable of providing innumerable hours of enjoyable gameplay. Whether you wish to explore strange new worlds and civilizations, or battle a space mobster penguin in a flying saucer, the adventure is there awaiting you.  By and large Starbound is a stressless, carefree, and charming sort of game. While some of the bosses in the game can be somewhat challenging, it is not the sort of game that invites much frustration. Others may comment that the controls can, in some instances, feel a little clunky; I wasn’t too pleased I could only use my weapons while standing still… but overall, I cannot complain, and I cannot say that minor nitpicks like that have ever bothered me. There have only been two areas in which I have experienced minor frustration.  Number one cause of minor frustration: some of the modes of the game, such as Survivor, cause you to lose pixels (currency) and drop all of your current items upon death… and if you drop your items in an out-of-the-way, hard-to-access location (like a cave on the far side of a planet), it can become rather irritating to attempt to regain your lost inventory (you might die SEVERAL MORE TIMES in the process, only worsening your situation). However, players can choose to use the Casual mode instead, in which no pixels or items are lost upon death in the game.  Number two cause of minor frustration: while Starbound provides a lot of in-game teaching to help you learn how to use various items and equipment, there were a number of instances in which I had to Google how to do something I thought would be intuitive – how to plant and grow crops, how to build blocks with the matter manipulator, how to eat food, how to craft certain items, etc. Maybe this is solely my problem, caused by obliviousness, and others find these actions more intuitive. However, for me, at the start of the game, I often found myself fiddling around, confused about how to proceed with what I thought should have been simple tasks. But – that said, that was only a minor frustration at the start of gameplay. I have come to realize that Starbound is a lot about exploring options and discovering things on your own – and with that mindset, learning how to do new actions in a casual exploratory-sense became a lot of fun, and I lost all such taskmastering concerns about how to do things.   And that really is what makes Starbound so enjoyable: exploration. Exploration of planets and planets and planets and planets. Exploration of desert biomes, frozen mountain biomes, jungle biomes, ocean biomes, even flesh biomes. Exploration of various alien species civilizations. Exploration of worlds with one-eyed cat ghost alien creatures, fire-breathing bird alien creatures, hopping carrot alien creatures. Exploration of how to cook rice or build rope or construct shields or upgrade your space vessel. I will admit I haven't gotten too far into the story, even having done about 36 hours of gameplay... but I don't mind. It's just too fun to explore. I'll casually mosey my way through the story eventually.  I suspect some people could get bored of the biomes available on Starbound alone, or of the quests, or of the music, or of the general overall “feel” of Starbound. The game carries with it a sort of simplicity. For me, though, and the other individuals I know who play Starbound… it is carefree and addicting.  Mods for this game are definitely worth checking out, as they provide new layers to Starbound, and many more different types of things to explore.   Starbound is a game I would recommend to many people. Again, it is charming. It is endearing. It has a smile-evoking, amusing, uplifting sort of atmosphere to it. It is a game I have already spent many hours playing, and plan to spend many, many more.

Were you disappointed by No Man's Sky? Then play Starbound and feel everything you wish No Man's Sky made you feel.  You can go from planet to planet, encounter settlements themed around the various playable races, complete quests given to you by settlers, convincing them to join your crew and take residence on your ship, and thus allowing you to acquire more advanced licenses used to expand that ship.  You can mine in relative safety on the surface, or dig deep and discover caverns of rarer materials. You can then use those materials to craft better armor or higher grade work stations used to build and make better equipment.  You can find a multitude of weapons with various abilities inherent to them to suppliment their basic attacks, then use those weapons to combat creatures and npcs of the many races in themed dungeons.  You can harvest crops found growing in the different biomes and use them to prepare foods that grant buffs, and you can use seeds you find to build your own farm.  You can build your OWN settlements block by block and fill them with tenants that will reward you with money and gifts. If you fill their rooms with race-specific furniture you can even make your own themed settlement filled with a race or type of tenant of your choosing.  And you can choose between wandering from planet to planet, star to star, in search riches and adventure, or following the main questline and exterminating the great evil looming over the universe.  Basically, the number of things to do and differnt playstyles to utilize is massive and this game is one of the best open-universe adventure games to come to the indie scene in a long time.

I have been playing Starbound here and there for years. Seeing it grow has been a very enjoyable experience, but seeing what it has become has been both amazing and awful.  While there are some systems in place that I am very pleased with how they've evolved, there are others that still feel shallow or lackluster. Take the Combat for example, no matter what you do in the early game you will inevitably get damaged after almost every encounter with the indigenous alien life which forces you to pop salve after salve in between every encounter. Combine this with the hunger system and you are sure to die the first time you go underground for an extended expedition for Core Fragments.   Another big mistep in my opinion is the way they handled death post-alpha. It used to be you lost pixels(the in-game currency) at a flat pecent rate upon death, you would keep all of your inventory but be forced to respawn on the ship. Now when you die, you lose building materials, health items and ores AS WELL AS the pixel penalty from before.   Chuckle Fish, this isn't the Souls series. I'm here to explore, build and collect, not fight with the boring and broken combat system just to die time and time again to something ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like being conered by four monster that fell ontop of me after a sandvalanche caused them to pile up proximity hitting me every half second. If you wanted the combat to feel 'tactical' or 'stategic' as you've plainly put it before - only do the damage when they attack, not when they are touching you. That mechanic has always been dumb and I'm surprised it passed so many updates without a change.  All in all, this game is worth the buy. It is massive and overall an enjoyable experience. Although with how many years we've been beta testing this for them, you'd think it would be a masterpeice. . . oh well.

I waited to review this game for a LONG time. I was with it from the extremely early stages, back when there was a temperature gauge and you used a beacon to lure a penguin boss to fight him. There was and extremely long period of nothing, where the game had some stuff to do, but the missions were long and dragged out, and most of the planets looked the same(except when you found one of the very rare special biomes on a planet, like eyeball or crystal). The missions lacked depth, were tedious, and were really just devices to get you to find some of the cooler(but still rare) biomes. It was like this for 2 or 3 years. Then, for a couple months, they dev team went silent when updating the stable build. It was a sad period for starbound. Then, suddenly and without warning, 1.0 hit. Starbound was out of early access. The several month quiet peroid made sense, because the devs LOADED the game with new stuff: 1. Steam multipplayer 2. Mod support via the Steam Workshop 3. Fixed mission system that had story and was ENGAGING 4. Completely reworked the lore, and added an intro mission that serves as a tutorial 5. More weapons 6. More biomes(just a few, they already have many) 7. More furniture, items, food, craftables, and lots of other stuff.  It was sad to see one of my favorite games(back in the day) go under the ice, but it has resurfaced in full glory, and that gives me hope again. Plus, if there is and issue with the game, someone can just fix it with a mod on the workshop :p (*cough cough optimization cough cough*)

Going to edit this review for Starbound as it exists right now. I have currently played about 17 hours of it and willing to write an honest review of my impressions.   And for those of you who hate reading: Its good.   Its a fun game, with a lot of spirit put into it. For all those Terraria enthusiasts out there, there is technically more loot to use, more areas to visit, more creatures to fight, more things available to do. Theres simply more of pretty much everything.   And that is where I like to start my personal opinion on Starbound: Quantity does not equal Quality.  Starbound is good, and incorperates a lot of passion and ideas into a game that certainly will consume a lot of hours if you choose to dedicate them here. You can collect, farm, fight, and pretty much do everything you could in Terraria, plus additional features.   What the game doesn't have is not content, its quality. Combat in Terraria, movement, even building were polished to a mirror sheen. Less content was used to create a game that absolutely was worth hours of gameplay and enjoyment.   In its own regard, Starbound is an excellent independant game. Its finally been released, and it contains a real game, that is worth the asking price of $15.00. I personally have not felt like I experienced much of the game as of yet, and already I've put in about 18 hours, so from a PPH standpoint, this game is mathmatically worth your money.   To the developers, I have one thing to say: Terraria was many things, but at its heart it was a exploration game. You say Starbound is an exploration game, but I feel no reason to explore. There is no breathtaking vista, no hidden oasis, no secret place in your endless space. It is space, and while you have included much in it.... would you personally be excited to live in the universe you built?

With Starbound, you are thrust onto a random planet, your character blasted out of their homeworld for some reason, depending on what race you are, and then for a while drifted in space until you run out of fuel, and must jump down onto a random world. The world generation is unique, from anywhere to normal pine trees, to tall floral flower-trees, to pink trees with fluffy leaves, and dirts/grass of all sorts of colors, the vegetation is brought spot-on, with added in plants from real life or ones the devs decided to make up. Along with that, there are many randomized structures with enemies and loot. You start out by gathering a few materials and stuff, before managing to get your ship up and running to go to different planets for things- plants, minerals, items, etc. However, I'm not going to explain everything after that- you can figure that by yourself  Randomization- Planets with many biomes/sub-biomes, with different structures and loot that you can get per planet. You may be surprised or not so surprised at what you see. Guns and swords(non-crafted ones) with various stats, if you get enough you might find one that fits your playstyle, or one that has a really funny name. Creatures that include some squid-Cthulu monster spit blood that explodes at you, or some boxer creature with no eyes and a giant mouth that has the power of levitation. Building- The amount of materials you can find over the course of adventuring allows you to make so many different houses, including rainbow houses with unicorn statues, Japanese-style housing, or just a basic wood house with a giant library. It's yours to create, after enough adventuring. Music- I know, this is an opinion, but I have NEVER seen an as-great orchestral soundtrack able to convey emotions of all kinds, encouraging for the building of amazing mansions or running across the grass, ready to explore new things. It rivals legendary composers like Beethoven or Bach. Customizability- It's possible to customize your character in many ways, whether its their outfit, skin color, etc, the beginning character creator is, no-doubt, above-average in my eyes, where it is just enough to know this is MY character, made by ME! Then, you build your own building, etc etc, with the amazing music playing, and overall you feel like you're having a great time. As the game progresses, you grab more gear that is cool, and you end up leaving happy.    Dark Side- Little story, the quests are mere fetch-quests or dungeon runs that seem to have little point besides getting better gear and unlocking new planets. People who don't enjoy the game just rush past it, hardly experiencing the good gameplay left in the void.    Overall, Starbound is a great sandbox game with excellent music, good customizability, well-randomized worlds, creatures, etc and some of the best building possible to any 2d game. However, there is little story, and people seem to rush through the game rather than enjoy it properly.

TLDR: Worth it if you like these types of games (loot based). You get the core game and current modding + future potential for a very reasonable price.   First purchased around 2014 would play once in a while during a larger release generally with friend(s). Wasn't quite sure when the game first came out but eventually got it. There have been many changes between then and release, some have been good and others uncertain.  Now that the full release has finally happened, what are the main changes? -Main story line. Something for those that need a goal. Also includes tentacles, who doesn't like tentacles? -Farming. Mainly Flora. Fauna are mainly to get rare crafting ingrediants. -Shipmates. Get NPC's in singleplayer or even bigger pizza parties in multiplayer. -Pokemon. You can capture and battle with the critters. -Quests. Mini quests from NPC's give more things to do. -Explore. Biome updates, new loot, new dungeons, strip planets bare, etc. -Fishing! An update added quite the interesting little fishing game. -Collect. Do you like collecting stuff? Between fossils, monster statues, food, and fish there are lots of things to mark off your checklist. Or ignore it all!  As mentioned above regarding changes, an example is reigning in the damage numbers. Was going on an adventure and visited an end game tier solar system after just starting. Was able to slowly make my way around an asteroid field picking up good resources while avoiding monsters and barely suriving the cold when I stumbled upon an abandoned storage facility of some sort. First course of action is to check the room for loot then swipe all the furniture and decorative blocks then proceed to the next room. Standard procedure. In the last room a sniper rifle with an absurd amount of damage was found and it was amazing.. of course I'd sometimes not use it in order to have a challenge but it was looted fair and square.  We can still skip ahead in the tiers a bit and ultimately this is a sandbox style game so there is no wrong way to play. Unfortunately that storage base, temperature, and a few other things were removed. Mods exist to bring many of these back and Chucklefish has been updating the game post-release so they could be refined and re-added.  Plus there are large changing mods such as Frackin Universe bringing significant changes and if you want crazy weapons back there are other mods for the job.. or make your own! Oh and it's DRM free so you can't always rely on the time played value.  This makes Starbound a great purchase even at full price.

As much as I like this game, even I can admit that it is incredibly flawed. PROS:  -Looks Pretty  -Good Sountrack  -Very active modding community  -Can be quite fun with friends  -Interesting story CONS:  -Story too easy to complete and is very short  -Poor monster AI  -Very, VERY poorly optimized.  -No way to disable certain settings in-game, you have to go to the .ini file  -No frame-skip settings leading to smooth gameplay, but impossible frame lag at times, making the game unplayable.  -Insane FPS drops in an already slow game  -Devs seem to ignore anything about FPS drops, and claim that they 'know about the problem'  -Worlds can take ages to load; Chunk loading is very poor and needs to be fixed.  -Quests can break for seemingly no reason and not work  -Far too easy to progress in game. Even on higher difficulties, you just take more damage. Main story can be beaten in a few hours without having to ever upgrade any crafting tables, if you know what youre doing.  -Unsatisfying Combat  -Feels far too easy in general actually. 'An ocean miles wide, but inches deep'    The game is fun but all of these problems may make you really not enjoy this game. Get it for you and a few friends and have some fun together. Dont try to take it too seriously or anything. Just my two cents.     TL;DR: Broken but pretty fun with friends. Way better with mods.

Starbound is fantastic. For those of you who were told this was similar to Terraria: yes. It is similar, however they are two completely different games. The only real similarity I would point out is that they are both 2D-Sidescrolling Sandbox games. The genre is the same, but the execution is very different.   Starbound is more of an RPG style, where there is an actual story and quests to play through, as opposed to Terraria which, if I remember right, just has the bosses to kill, hard mode, and the Angler's Fishing quests.   In Starbound, you choose what race you want to be, start the game, learn the backstory, and are thrown into your ship, which is pretty destroyed and out of fuel. Go do stuff, find orange shards which unlock an outpost, and continue your story from there with a little bit of guidance.  I won't spoil anything past that, but it's definitely worth a play. Solid 8/10 for me, only being marked down because the story is a little short if you know what you're doing. For me, this causes replayability issues. I also know that it has workshop support, so there are lots of mods to keep people playing after the story is well over. If I'm not mistaken, Chucklefish is still adding to the game as well, so you have that to look forward to.

I have played Starbound multiple times during its development and the game has changed significantly in that time, so it is hard to keep straight in my head what is and what was in the game. It would be easier if they didn't take so long releasing the game, it's not like I'm bitter or anything.  Comparisons to Terraria are inevitable so let's get that out of the way. The planets are inevitably much more shallow than a Terraria world, there's maybe two interesting things per planet but there's a whole galaxy of them. Starbound offers space hopping from planet to planet and spending a little time on each to grab what's useful. If you prefer to get attached to your environment you may be left wanting, you can save planets and build your home base on one, but any individual planet will not offer a depth of exploration.  Progression is mostly done through plot missions, typically you need an item to survive on more challenging planets and something nasty needs to be killed to obtain this item. There's also the usual mine new ore to build better tools to mine new ore system.  Combat is fairly decent: melee is the typical hit things with large weapons affair but I found the guns to have a satisfying feel to them.  I would recommend this game but I also had a lot of context going into Starbound so you should probably play a whole bunch of Minecraft and Terraria first, and then because you're bored of mining games have some friends do all the heavy lifting in the Starbound progression system while you make a monkey house.

A wonderfully endearing space game that's only gotten better with subsequent updates.  It's cozy and familiar with it's core crafting, combat, and exploration elements, yet offers so much more once the player unlocks interplanetary travel. Rather than having every single biome contained to one large world, Starbound allows you to skip between and explore various planets in thousands of systems. There's many, many different environments and civilizations that you can find; arid desert plains with gnomes living under the surface, eyeball tree forests settled by knights, swampy jungles filled with planty cannibals... even expansive oceans where you've got to dive deep to find any intelligent life at all. It's a vast and varied universe that Starbound offers, with enough variance in weapons, armor, and gadgets to keep most anyone happy on their adventures.  When it's time to make a home, the player's given a sizable variety of different materials and styles to choose from-- granted they've collected them on their travels. For those who prefer building to adventuring, the only disappointment I've found was being unable to add smooth diagonal slopes. Beyond that, the choices offered were phenomenal. You can keep tenants that will periodically give you gifts as rent, or offer quests that may allow you to employ them to your ship's crew. You can raise adorable variations of fluffalo, set up a farm of alien veggies, structure crafting labs, build a teleportation network, and construct whatever buildings and homes you might imagine. If living on a planet's surface isn't even to your tastes, the player's ship is expandable and can be fully renevated within.  Starbound suits a myriad of fancies if exploration and crafting games are what you enjoy. It offers a universe full of interesting discoveries, exciting adventures, cozy homes, cute characters, and an ever-charming atmosphere.
